This sounds awesome! It could totally fit with the unique piglin society. Each banner could have the snout pattern, but other designs would characterize the banners of individual clans. Perhaps each clan would specialize in a particular field depending whether:
they have a bastion remnant in command (raising hoglins, defending structures, growing nether wart and crimson fungus)...
a brute is in their clan or not (take leadership, aggro towards player)
they wander...crimson forest? (Hunt hoglins, gather certain materials, especially gold)

Allay is a good choice. I believe that this can happen in the Stronghold library with a tiny chance (alternatively, it will just wander around the library, either it will be empty or there will be silverfish).

I think the illagers should remain as enemies instead as being able to be befriendable.

We SHOULD be able to friend the illagers. It will give the game a more interesting concept. Think about going into a village after gaining an Illager army. Iron golems would attack you because you would be an enemy. I don't get why we can't as the villagers are scam artists.

I don't think the illagers will think that you're their friend, perhaps they'll just consider you as a non-hostile towards them. So when you face a band of illagers, like pillager patrol, you can throw a bunch of emeralds, 15 or 20 towards the captain and so they would consider that you don't want to mess with them. The same goes to the outpost, you throw emeralds, and those dude will let you go inside their post. However you are not befriend them and they won't absolutely follow you on a raid. They'll just not gonna hurt or kill you, as long as you keep your fist away.

Day 2- student (trades start)

Day 3- Intern

Day 4+- Adult

This basically sounds like a librarian, but better.  And that's the problem.  Librarians would be worthless if you're more likely to get the awesome book you want from the scholar.
Maybe if the scholar was extremely rare it would balance out.
ClayGoddessSari is completely correct; this is not a balanced idea.
Good idea but I think it should have some kind of new enchantment that you can only get from the scholar and he should be rare.
Bad idea. I like the librarian.
Librarian.

I believe this has some potential. Imagine splitting these into librarian and scholar.
First of all the librarian workbench would become the bookshelf. There is a great post on how the bookshelf would work: https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/community/posts/360009302932-Bookshelves-are-unexciting-Let-s-fix-that, and the scholar would be using the lectern as their workbench.
The librarian would trade bookshelves, books, enchanted books, name tags, clock and a candle which post can be found here https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/community/posts/360012327351-Candles-
The scholar would trade paper, black dye, sticks, book and quill, feather, maps and some new pre written books by Mojang, taking up the Knowledge Books place, which would make up some stories that would serve the purpose guide the player, like a tale of a character that once made a certain shape of obsidian blocks and never was seen again; things that would hint the Player.

I am also doing a villager trading station, and I just don't understand why there is not a tool or a direct mechanic to manually link villagers to workstations/beds. Villagers' interactions with linkable objects are very hard to manipulate when you start to have a lot of them. After many hours of losing my mind, I can say that there is room for improvement. The villager linking mechanic is cringe and clumsy.

In Minecraft Dungeons, all the undead are controlled by nameless necromancers from a forgotten temple, there is an alliance between the Illagers and these necromancers.
On the other hand, there are also spiders and creepers that for some reason only attack the player, this is definitely worth fixing.
a friendly pillager and a new zombie variant would be a really nice addition to the game and would make for some interesting gameplay.
That goes under the assumption Minecraft came first there is clearly an alex statue killing the enderdragon undead should attack illagers

This change increases the grind, for what reason exactly?

It incentivizes the player to kill Villagers, does nothing to provide players with alternative options to maintain their gear, and doesnt affect loot tables in chests for mending books to offset the change to villagers. It just makes a trading hall take longer. Once you hit the anvil limit, your gear is effectively retired unless you luck out on RNG or cull dozens of villagers.

Additionally, this affects ALL books. No one gets everything they need from looted chests. This change has too many unintended consequences. Are they earth shattering? No, but they are annoying (not fun or interesting).

This doesnt exactly entice players to want to grind for the new trimmed armor either, let alone wear it and risk it breaking. Getting 1 (one) set of netherite gear takes long enough now with the template system, and it was already grindy.

Free time is not a gameplay resource developers can make use of to artificially inflate the challenge of a game.

Changing the anvil system would be a better use of resources, offer players more options, is lore friendly, immersive and would be better recieved by players.

Thank you for listening to my TEDtalk.
